abstract.text: A container that provides information about and access to the image, video, or Live Photo content of an asset to be edited.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To edit an asset’s photo or video content:
object that represents the photo or video to be edited.
Apply your edits to the asset. To allow a user to continue working with the edit later (for example, to adjust the parameters of a photo filter), create a
object. For photo- or video-only assets, use the editing output’s properties to provide edited asset data. For Live Photo assets, create a
object to edit the Live Photo content.
Use a photo library change block to commit the edit. In the block, create a
property to the editing output that you created. For more details, see
You can also edit assets from photo editing extensions. In this case, instead of working with a
object, you implement methods in the
object when your extension begins editing. When editing is complete, Photos requests a
object that contains the edited asset content.

abstract.text: Provide custom functionality in the Photos app by bundling an app extension.
Provide the same interactive playback of Live Photos as in the iOS Photos app.
Make a request to modify and save a photo or video asset.
Keys indicating the status of an asset content editing request, used in the completion handler of the
method.
Work with image and video assets that the Photos app manages, including those from iCloud Photos and Live Photos.
A description of the edits made to an asset’s photo, video, or Live Photo content, which allows your app to reconstruct or revert the effects of prior editing sessions.
A representation of an image, video, or Live Photo in the Photos library.
An enumeration of asset playback styles that dictate how to present an asset to the user.
Returns whether the asset supports the specified editing operation.
Cancels a request for editing the asset’s content.
Requests asset information for beginning a content editing session.
A request to create, delete, change metadata for, or edit the content of a Photos asset, for use in a photo library change block.
The output of an asset content editing session.
Values identifying possible actions an asset can support, used by the
method.
Constants identifying specific variations of asset media, such as panorama or screenshot photos, and time-lapse or high-frame-rate video.
Identifies the general type of an asset, such as image or video.
A container that provides information about and access to the image, video, or Live Photo content of an asset to be edited.
An object that describes the most recent edit to the asset’s content.
The video asset, as an
object.
The video asset, as an
object.
The date and time when the asset was originally created.
An image of the asset’s contents, appropriately sized for display.
The Exif display orientation of the full-size image file.
The URL to a file that contains the full-sized image data.
The unedited Live Photo content of the editing input.
The location information that was saved with the asset.
The subtypes of the asset, identifying special kinds of assets such as a panoramic photo or a high-frame-rate video.
The type of the asset, such as video or audio.
The style in which to present this content to the user.
The uniform type identifier for the asset’s image or video data.
An identifier for an asset content editing session.
A set of options affecting the delivery of image or video data when you request to edit the content of a Photos asset.
A container to which you provide the results of editing the photo, video, or Live Photo content of a Photos asset.
An editing session for modifying the photo, video, and audio content of a Live Photo.
A container that provides image content for a single frame of a Live Photo in an editing context.
An object that manages access and changes to the user’s photo library.
A protocol your custom view controller class implements to provide a user interface for your Photos extension.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
